Award.AwardTitle: The Creation and Management of the Southwest Amazon: Landscape and Sociopolitical Organization in the Llanos de Mojos, Bolivia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the support of the National Science Foundation, Dr. John Walker will work with an international team of archaeologists, students and other stakeholders during two seasons of archaeological research in the Bolivian Amazon. This project compares settlement within agricultural landscapes and analyzes it as evidence for how society was organized. Every agricultural landscape reflects the local history and sociopolitical organization associated with its construction and maintenance. Debates about society, politics and agricultural intensification often focus on centralized control, leaving details of local organization understudied. At the largest scale, the organization of agriculture by a strong, centralized authority is reflected in a strong spatial pattern. At intermediate scales, agriculture is linked to settlements that correspond to the communities that organized agricultural labor. At the smallest scale, organization of agriculture is correlated with an atomized landscape, dominated by local conditions. To understand intensive agriculture, the focus must shift to the analysis of local spatial and sociopolitical organization.

Mojos is a seasonally flooded tropical savanna in the Bolivian Amazon in which hundreds of square kilometers of agricultural features are still visible. Like many farmers around the world, Mojeños sculpted their landscape into fields, canals, causeways and mounds that improved soil conditions and controlled water. Over many generations, they built a variety of environments that both conditioned daily activities and were created by them. These landscapes were built incrementally, reflecting both the history and structure of farming societies.

The project focuses on two study areas in Central Mojos, in a region of earthworks west of the Mamoré River, near Santa Ana del Yacuma. First, area excavations are used to examine settlement for evidence of communal activity associated with defense, ritual, and feasting. Second, on-the-ground survey, collection of diagnostic ceramics and test excavation is used to locate and define settlement within each of two agricultural landscapes. Finally, laboratory analyses are used to build ceramic chronology, reconstruct environment, and obtain evidence of the use of ceramics for cooking, brewing and serving.

The intellectual merit of the project is threefold: First, it will help reorient archaeology towards to more comprehensive studies of the locations where individuals and groups carried out daily tasks. Second, this project is relevant to how agricultural landscapes were successfully managed (or not) over the long term. These archaeological landscapes are records of alternative ways to create, transform and manage resources. Third, by combining the archaeological record of settlement and agriculture, it contributes to the reinterpretation of the Amazon Basin as a network of anthropogenic landscapes.

The broader impacts of the study include the development of an international research community. The project will continue to develop connections between institutions in the US and Bolivia including universities, national, departmental, local and municipal governments, museums and indigenous communities. Potential collaboration with institutions in Brazil and the UK will open a wide range of opportunities for both Bolivian and US students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Archaeological GIS Project of the Beni carried out archaeological research and analysis from 2010-2014, funded by NSF grant number 1026529.

The Archaeological GIS Project of the Beni (known by ProSIGAB, its Spanish acronym) contributed significantly to our understanding of sustainable agriculture in the Amazon Basin, of social and political organization in the pre-Columbian Amazon, and of the deep history of the Llanos de Mojos, Bolivia. The project carried out five excavations in two forest islands, producing a new sequence of 24 radiocarbon dates. In combination with previous project research in 1996-1997 (NSF dissertation improvement grant 9610312), these dates refine a 7000-year chronological sequence, including between 1,000 and 2,400 years of intensive agriculture.

These results suggest that forest islands were occupied and reoccupied for many centuries, and in some cases millennia. About 75% of forest islands (38 of 50) show evidence of permanent occupation, and where larger excavations have been carried out, these occupations range between 400 and 2400 years. Shorter occupations (400-600 years) are indicated at islands with two excavations each, while longer occupations (1800-2400 years) are indicated at islands with three excavations, suggesting that the length of occupation is related to the intensity of research. In turn, this suggests that large forest islands were occupied continuously over long periods. All excavated forest islands were in direct association with raised fields.

The project demonstrated that ring ditches, a distinctive form of earthen architecture known from much of Southern and Southwestern Amazonia, are found along the Yacuma and Rapulo Rivers in west-central Mojos, and are found earlier than better known examples in eastern Mojos. Ring ditches were previously unknown from this area.

The project continues to maintain close relations with the Museo Arqueológico Regional de la Provincia Yacuma (MARYA), a regional museum located in Santa Ana del Yacuma, and one of the only museums of its size in Bolivia.

Undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Central Florida, in Orlando participated by mapping archaeological features from satellite imagery, and working in small groups to interpret and analyze their work. In the Bolivian Amazon, students from both the United States and Bolivia worked together, advancing research and receiving training in the field. Most project participants are continuing their graduate education, after having received training in field methods.

Finally, ProSIGAB opened discussions for collaborative work with Université Montpellier 2 in France, the Museo de Historia Natural Noel Kempff Mercado in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, and the Universidad Mayor de San Andres in La Paz, Bolivia. This future collaboration will include ecologists and archaeologists from France, Bolivia and the United States.
